title: Americans in Ghosn Escape Case Ask U.S. to Halt Extradition
sub_head: Attorneys for Michael and Peter Taylor, accused of helping auto titan Carlos Ghosn out of Japan, made the request in a letter to Secretary of State Antony Blinken
body:
Two Americans accused of helping former auto titan Carlos Ghosn escape from Japan have made a last-ditch appeal to the Biden administration to stop the pair from being extradited to Japan or to put new conditions on their extradition.
Attorneys for Michael L. Taylor and his son Peter M. Taylor sent a letter early this month to Secretary of State Antony Blinken asking for a delay of 30 to 60 days for the new administration to take a look at whether the pair should be extradited, according to a copy of the letter viewed by The Wall Street Journal.
The State Department has the final say in extradition cases, which are considered diplomatic matters. The Trump-era State Department had cleared the Taylors’ extradition. The U.S. Supreme Court on Saturday declined to take up the case, marking the end of any legal appeals.
If U.S. officials decide to proceed with the extradition, the Taylors’ lawyers asked the State Department to put conditions on the surrender, including that the nine months the Taylors served in a U.S. jail count towards any prison sentence they might receive in Japan. The letter also requests that the Taylors serve any Japanese prison sentence in the U.S. or a U.S. military detention facility in Japan.
The Taylors at minimum have requested a delay in extradition until at least Feb. 25, the day after they are scheduled to receive their second Covid-19 vaccine, according to Paul V. Kelly, one of their attorneys. There is a Covid-19 outbreak at the Norfolk County jail near Boston where the Taylors have been held since U.S. authorities arrested them in May at the request of Japanese officials.
